report_title: Group Purchasing Organizations in the US
executive_summary: The Group Purchasing Organizations (GPOs) industry is composed of entities that leverage the purchasing power of groups of businesses to obtain collective discounts from vendors. GPOs earn most of their revenue by charging an administrative fee to vendors. For the past five years, demand for GPO services increased as the improving economy stimulated demand for various downstream industries, including the manufacturing and food service sectors. Meanwhile, rising access to health insurance drove demand from healthcare providers. The healthcare sector is by far the largest market for the industry, accounting for more than 60.0% of industry revenue. According to the Healthcare Supply Chain Association, a trade association representing the largest healthcare GPOs in the United States, more than 95.0% of all hospitals hold at least one GPO membership, and about 72.0% of all purchases that hospitals make are done using GPO contracts. Consequently, demand for medical services strongly affects demand for GPO services. As a result, over the past five years, industry revenue has been growing at an annualized 2.2%, and is expected to reach $6.3 billion in 2023. Despite this growth, profit has slightly declined because GPOs are limited in their ability to raise prices.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: The Healthcare Industry is the Most Significant Demand Source for GPOs
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The healthcare industry has been a primary source of demand for GPOs, as providers seek to reduce costs and improve patient outcomes through group purchasing and value-based purchasing initiatives. COVID-19 also impacted demand for GPO services, with increased demand for personal protective equipment (PPE) and other medical supplies leading to higher purchasing volumes and tighter supply chains. At the same time, the pandemic also highlighted the importance of supply chain resilience and the need for GPOs to help their members navigate supply chain disruptions and shortages. According to the Healthcare Supply Chain Association, a trade association representing the largest GPOs in the United States, more than 95.0% of all hospitals held at least one GPO membership, and about 72.0% of all purchases that hospitals make are done using GPO contracts.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: GPOs Increasingly Rely on Technology to Provide Value for Members
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: GPOs have increasingly focused on data analytics and benchmarking tools to analyze procurement spend and performance, identify cost-saving

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Both Competition and Consolidation Have Risen in the Industry
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The number of GPOs operating in the market has grown, including new entrants and smaller regional or specialty GPOs. This has increased competition among GPOs for members and contracts. GPOs have expanded their services beyond traditional procurement to include other areas like data analytics, benchmarking, and consulting. This has enabled GPOs to differentiate themselves and offer more value to their members. One of the most significant examples of consolidation in the GPO industry was the merger of two of the largest healthcare GPOs, Vizient and MedAssets, in 2015. The merger created one of the largest GPOs in the healthcare industry, with a membership base of over 4,100 hospitals and $100.0 billion in purchasing volume.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: A Shift Toward Value-Based Purchasing is Anticipated to Occur
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: GPOs will increasingly focus on value-based purchasing, emphasizing the quality and outcomes of products and services rather than just the price. This will require GPOs to work more closely with their members to understand their needs and goals and to help them identify the products and

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: The Focus on Technology Will Likely Continue
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: GPOs will continue to invest in technology to improve their services and offerings. This will include data analytics, artificial intelligence, and machine learning to help members make more informed purchasing decisions and optimize their supply chains. GPOs are developing mobile applications that enable members to purchase on the go and access pricing and inventory information from their mobile devices. This improves member convenience and allows them to make more informed purchasing decisions.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: GPOs May Seek to Expand Outside of the Healthcare Market
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: While GPOs have traditionally focused on healthcare and foodservice industries, there is potential for them to increase their presence within other sectors in the future. GPOs could offer purchasing services and expertise to retailers, helping them source products more efficiently and cost-effectively. This could include negotiating contracts with suppliers, providing access to e-procurement systems, and leveraging their purchasing power to obtain better pricing. GPOs could offer purchasing services and expertise to construction companies, helping them source building materials and other supplies more efficiently and cost-effectively. This could include negotiating contracts with suppliers, providing access to e-procurement systems, and leveraging their purchasing power to obtain better pricing.

industry_definition: This industry includes organizations that leverage the purchasing power of groups of businesses to obtain collective discounts from vendors.

threats: Number of people with private health insurance

key_trends: While a handful of large GPOs dominate the market, there are also many smaller and specialized GPOs serving specific industries or regions. This competition has led to greater innovation and a focus on delivering value-added services to members.

The competitive landscape of the GPO industry is constantly evolving, with new entrants and strategic partnerships driving consolidation and shifting market dynamics. As the industry continues to grow and expand into new markets and industries, GPOs will need to adapt to changing customer needs and preferences and continue to differentiate themselves through the quality and breadth of their services.

GPOs have increasingly embraced technology to enhance their services and offerings, with a focus on e-procurement, data analytics and automation. This has enabled GPOs to provide more value to their members by streamlining procurement processes, improving supply chain visibility and driving cost savings.
The GPO industry has seen increased consolidation over the past five years, with larger players acquiring smaller companies and expanding their reach. This has resulted in increased competition.

market_segmentation.segment_description: The healthcare market dominates the Group Purchasing Organizations (GPOs) industry. According to the Government Accounting Office, about 98.0% of US hospitals use GPOs to purchase medical supplies and products.

Grocery store purchases through GPOs include fresh and frozen produce, fresh and frozen meats, dairy, dry goods, disposables and beverages. Additionally, these GPOs will often assist in purchasing ancillary products to the food industry, like glassware, flatware, serving dishes, cookware, kitchen equipment, and storage bins. The largest operator in this market is FoodBuy LLC, which has an estimated buying power of $5.0 billion. Similarly, on a smaller scale, farmers in the agricultural market often form cooperatives to purchase items like chemicals, feed, fertilizer, seed, and other inputs.

GPOs are particularly useful in this market because of the significant expense of manufacturing equipment. In addition, established relationships between buyers and sellers can help ensure the quality of the products and even expedite the sales cycle so that manufacturers can be sure to meet demand. GPOs in this market look to deliver savings on purchasing raw materials, services, and components. These GPOs are particularly attractive to smaller manufacturers, as they provide bargaining power and therefore an opportunity to compete against large, global manufacturers.
Demand from other markets is limited.
Demand from other markets is limited.
Other GPO markets include government, retail, veterinary services and nonprofit organizations.

products_and_services.product_description: Management consulting services provided by GPOs.
Services related to supply chain management.
Fees paid by members of the GPO group.

tier_1_suppliers: Medical Instrument & Supply Manufacturing in the US
tier_2_suppliers: Medical Device Manufacturing in the US
tier_1_buyers: Primary Care Doctors in the US

demand_determinants.determinant_description: Hospitals, manufacturers, and legal professionals frequently delay purchases during difficult financial times and periods of recession. Conversely, businesses demand higher quantities of goods as corporate profit increases, increasing demand for the services provided by group purchasing organizations. Corporate profit is expected to increase in 2023, representing a potential opportunity for the industry.

business_locations.location_description: The southeast region of the United States has several rapidly growing healthcare markets, including Florida, Georgia, and North Carolina. These markets offer significant business opportunities for GPOs. Like the west region, the southeast region has several major healthcare suppliers and manufacturers. This can make it easier for GPOs to establish supplier relationships and manage their supply chains.

The west region of the United States includes large and diverse healthcare markets like California, which can provide significant business opportunities for GPOs. The west region is home to many top universities and research institutions, which can provide a pool of skilled talent for GPOs to draw from. This can help GPOs to build a strong team with expertise in healthcare procurement, contracting, and supply chain management.

regulations_points.regulation_description: This federal law prohibits anyone from offering, paying, soliciting, or receiving remuneration in exchange for federal healthcare program business referrals.
This law prohibits physicians from referring patients to entities in which they have a financial interest.
The FTC monitors GPOs for potential antitrust violations, like collusion or price-fixing among competitors.
GPOs contracting with Medicare-participating suppliers must comply with specific Medicare regulations.
GPOs may be subject to additional state laws and regulations.

barriers_points.barrier_description: The GPO industry is in the growth stage.
The capital intensity level for GPOs is low.
The globalization level for GPOs is low and steady.

factors_increased_barrier: GPOs are subject to various federal and state regulations, like the Anti-Kickback Statute and the Stark Law, which can be complex and time-consuming. Compliance with these regulations can be costly and require significant legal resources.
factors_decreased_barrier: Starting a GPO can be expensive, requiring significant infrastructure, staff, and technology investment. This can make it difficult for new entrants to enter the market and compete with established GPOs.

GPOs rely on supplier relationships to negotiate discounts and other favorable pricing terms. Established GPOs may have an advantage in these relationships because of their reputation and track record.
GPOs require a skilled workforce with expertise in healthcare procurement, contracting, and supply chain management.

basis_points.basis_description: While a handful of large GPOs dominate the market, there are also many smaller and specialized GPOs serving specific industries or regions. This competition has led to greater innovation and a focus on delivering value-added services to members.
The competitive landscape of the GPO industry is constantly evolving, with new entrants and strategic partnerships driving consolidation and shifting market dynamics.

As the industry continues to grow and expand into new markets and industries, GPOs will need to adapt to changing customer needs and preferences and continue to differentiate themselves through the quality and breadth of their services.

concentration_points.concentration_description: The healthcare market, which accounts for about 60.0% of industry revenue, is highly concentrated, with the top six GPOs accounting for nearly 90.0% of all buying power and revenue for the market.
Notable mergers and acquisitions in the industry, such as Premier Inc. acquiring Innovatix and Essensa in 2018, and Vizient Inc. acquiring Intalere in 2021, have raised concentration levels.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Purchase Costs Have Fallen Over the Past Five Years
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Purchases represent an estimated 38.7% of the average industry operator's costs in 2023. As the industry does not purchase the products and services directly, purchases represent a smaller percentage of costs than other wholesaling industries.

Wages are estimated to represent 42.5% of the average industry operator's costs in 2023. Wages as a percentage of industry revenue have increased over the five years to 2023 because of the increased use of online communication and purchasing systems. As more skilled employees are being hired to design and develop online systems used for data and performance analysis of clients, average industry wages have increased.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Revenue volatility is tied to the healthcare industry
volatility_points.volatility_description: Changes in the healthcare industry, like shifts in healthcare policies, reimbursement rates, or healthcare spending, can impact the revenue of GPOs.
Mergers and acquisitions among GPOs or their member organizations can also affect revenue volatility.

technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Many GPOs have developed proprietary e-procurement platforms that allow members to search and compare products, place orders, track shipments, and access data and analytics on their purchasing activity.

FAQs.question: Are your sales heavily dependent on any single market, major customer or other single revenue stream?
FAQs.answer: A majority of GPOs specialize in healthcare supplies and equipment.

FAQs.question: How do economic downturns affect demand for your services?
FAQs.answer: Changes that support or hurt demand for healthcare impact GPO revenue.

FAQs.question: How does the size of your company affect its profitability and ability to grow operations?
FAQs.answer: Large GPOs have better negotiating power and are able to find better prices for supplies.

FAQs.question: Has your company explored growth opportunities via mergers or acquisitions?
FAQs.answer: Some GPOs have explored mergers as a way of growing their negotiating power.

FAQs.question: How has your company been able to implement technology into the purchasing process to make the most efficient buying process for customers?
FAQs.answer: Some GPOs are able to better manage their sales through online record keeping software.

FAQs.question: Does your company currently have an online platform for volume sales or plans to create an e-commerce platform?
FAQs.answer: A growing portion of GPO revenue comes from e-commerce and e-procurement.

FAQs.question: How have you adjusted to new regulations in the past decade? How have compliance costs been handled?
FAQs.answer: GPOs must manage what portion of their purchase expenses come from membership fees.

FAQs.question: How does your company ensure all relevant health and safety requirements are met?
FAQs.answer: Most GPOs do not handle the distribution of products, and therefore, do not need to be directly involved with maintaining safety requirements.

FAQs.question: How does volatility in the value of the dollar affect demand and profit?
FAQs.answer: As the dollar appreciates, supplies from overseas become relatively less expensive.

FAQs.question: What immediate challenges is your company likely to face financially over the next year?
FAQs.answer: Any changes in healthcare legislation will affect insurance enrollment and therefore, demand for industry services.

FAQs.question: How diverse are your links with suppliers? How vast is your product range? Do you hold long-term contracts with your suppliers?
FAQs.answer: Industry operators must establish and maintain good links with suppliers to be able to negotiate the lowest prices for their members.

FAQs.question: How does your company work to develop new products? In what ways have you innovated your service offerings?
FAQs.answer: The most successful industry operators must develop new services to provide to their members, such as e-procurement and consulting.

FAQs.question: Does your company have close relationships with several producers? How can you cultivate these relationships?
FAQs.answer: Industry operators purchase large amounts of a product at discount and must control the distribution of the products to organization members.

FAQs.question: How did your business perform when corporate profit remained low during the recession? Which industries do you primarily cater to?
FAQs.answer: Hospitals, manufacturers and legal professionals frequently delay purchases during difficult financial times and periods of recession.

FAQs.question: How does the number of people with private health insurance correlate with demand? How does your company keep track of this?
FAQs.answer: The number of physician visits is affected by the general health of the population and the ability of patients to pay for health services.

FAQs.question: In which medical industries do your clients primarily operate? How do you monitor and anticipate changes in demand for these industries?
FAQs.answer: Medical equipment and supplies manufacturing industries provide hospitals and healthcare providers with supplies.
